content:
Validator code is incorrect on this input:

100 100
X9.....9
9......9
...
9.......9

It's time limit exceeding.


Like most of the "backtrack" problems, I don't think the algorithmic complexity is determined by the authors and the validators. 
I know it's common on codingame to have such problems that are not proven as solvable in polynomial complexity (backtrack with pruning IS NOT polynomial complexity, even if there is so much on codingame (that's what make this website bad for algorithmic)).

And bad solutions will simply work because the test cases are bad and limited.


Also, for whoever tries to prove me wrong by saying "I solve your case instantaneously", send me your code so I can find one input that you can't solve. 
Because it's so common among codingamers to think that solving problems with heuristic means they solved the problem, when it's not the case.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: puzzle sympa. J'aurai hésité entre moyen et facile pour la difficulté

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Je me suis complètement planté d'algo à l'origine, mais l'algo final est sympa

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Le puzzle est fun à résoudre et permet d'aborder un sujet intéressant tel que les graphes
The test "Easy Life" has the wrong width input.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: this puzzle is worthy of being selected

I tested it, it's a cool one, but I disagree with Dwarfie, you have to parse the map and a few other stuffs, Medium is fine for this.

You don't need to backtrack because the tests/validators enables you to shortcut that using the good order of directions. Add one or two more tests/Validators to make the backtracking unavoidable.

Additionnaly, a test case with a loop on the map could be nice

example :
input : 
3
X12
3#4
567
output : 28

other example :
input :
3
123
4X5
678

output: 36

this test will turn algotithm that propage the best sum into failure.
You should add two constraints on H and W (width of the treasure map)

You talk about gold in the statement, but in output you state maximum possible sum. 
Sum of what? What does "possible" mean in this statement?

Please rephrase so it is clear what you want the player to calculate.
easy not medium ... solved in less than 5 minutes and  no backtracking needed

Thanks for your feedback !
I am always confused with puzzles difficulty (some "hard puzzles" are actually really easy compared to some "easy" ones.).
Switched the difficulty to "Easy".
I tried to rephrase to make it clearer. Please let me know if you think this is still confusing.

Agreed, even if it can be easily deduced, since it's not in the puzzle's scope.
I mean, it's trivial to deduce the W, and the H is already given but it would be nice to have nonetheless!
note that your algorithm fails with my second example

I disagree with the fact that parsing would make it medium (most puzzles need some kind of parsing) however it's true that a few more validators that would make the branching factor explode could be nice. Otherwise a simple brute force would be enough to solve the problem.
Corrected, thanks.
Brute force is medium level, there is no Easy puzzle proposed by the Codingame team that forces a bruteforce.

I disagree on that as well. Brute forcing is often the most basic way you can use to solve a problem (when time allows it). Sometimes you don't brute force the whole problem because you have early exits but still brute forcing is the easy way and a problem can't be flagged as medium just because it needs brute forcing and parsing (if the modelling is hardcore as well maybe I could reconsider my claim, but here it's not the case)

I agree with Jiway, it should be medium and tests are weak.
("Backtracking" is not really "brute-force" though, there are different degrees of sophistication in exhaustive search techniques. But maybe you are referring to the CG "brute-force" tag, which indeed tends to gather exhaustive search puzzles.)

Are you sure about that ? 
I just tested and it passed ?

Anyways, I added a test case with a loop as you suggested.
Agreed, done.

IMO this should be medium. Request to advanced coders (> level 30 or so); Some puzzles may seem easy to you but may not be for most beginners. 
Please see the difficulty level of the original easy/medium puzzles by CodinGame and use them as a reference to decide difficulty levels of a puzzle.

Nice puzzle by the way :)

it is not because lots of trivial or more-coc-than-puzzle have been accepted as easy for quest map hunt that the difficult of this puzzle is medium ... 

if we had tests using max constraints limit , why not ... but here it is not the case and the problem is not so hard ( i ask my nephew who is not a coder and just with paper and pencil he found how to do )

Can you prove that your solution has a complexity that handles the N = 100 and M = 100 limit for each valid grid?

Because first, backtracking algorithms are usually factorial complexity in worst cases, and second, if you don't even maintain backtracking, you're just lucky that the test cases are bad.

Here at best, if using naive dynamic programming, without pruning, the state space is still up to 2^(100*100) (number of possible cells visited until now), and pruning doesn't prune that much, unless you make wrong assomptions.
